info.game_comments: 2005 Ultimate Tournament of Champions Round 1, game 20.

(1, 1).clue: Francois Pilatre de Rozier tried to cross the Channel in one of these in 1785, but was killed in the attempt

(3, 1).clue: The national assn. devoted to this board game has a website where you can learn the "Word of the Day"

(4, 1).clue: Born in 1817, solo nature boy 1845-1847, became one with the earth in 1862

(5, 1).clue: The atomic numbers of hydrogen, helium & lithium

(1, 2).clue: The Channel meets the North Sea at this strait

(3, 2).clue: The Gov. Bradford Compact held its annual meeting in this Mass. town from 1946 to 2003; it now alternates with Kingston

(4, 2).clue: Born in 1775, showed "Sensibility" in 1811, never married, died in 1817

(5, 2).clue: Oklahoma, New Mexico & Arizona entered the Union as these states

(1, 3).clue: A song & a dance were named for this lady who swam the channel in 1926 & passed away at age 98 in 2003

(3, 3).clue: "For God and Country" is the motto of this "World's Largest Veterans Organization"

(4, 3).clue: Born in a hotel in 1888, took a "Long Day's Journney into Night" in a hotel in 1953

(5, 3).clue: According to the "World Almanac", they were the last 3 years of the 19th century

(1, 4).clue: La Manche, the French name for the channel, means this part of a shirt

(3, 4).clue: Founded in 1912, it's the Women's Zionist Organization of America

(4, 4).clue: Born in Prague in 1883, worked in insurance until 1922, died in '24, yet went on "Trial" in '25

(5, 4).clue: Martin Van Buren, William Henry Harrison & John Tyler were these number presidents

(6, 4).clue: Evidently, it's Latin for "from the first face"

(1, 5).clue: The "Isle of" this has been inhabited since prehistoric times; it was once called Vectis

(3, 5).clue: In 1952, the lily became the official logo of this organization that helps people with special needs & disabilities

(4, 5).clue: Born in 1854, was well-read in Gaol for 2 years, Paris-ed away in 1900

(5, 5).clue: The amendments against unreasonable searches, against self-incrimination & for a speedy trial

(6, 5).clue: "Inquistion" contestants know its Portugese for "act of the faith"

(1, 1).clue: Tired of holding this, Coco Chanel attached a chain to it & made history

(2, 1).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew reports.)  The body part that regulates light entering the eye & the similar part in a camera gave this old-time effect its name

(3, 1).clue: This royal thwarted a coup d'etat in 1981 & to us he'll always be King of Spain

(4, 1).clue: Francis Coppola brought this author's most famous work to the big screen

(5, 1).clue: 47 of the 48 constellations he listed in his "Almagest" around 150 B.C. are still recognized

(1, 2).clue: In 1926, Coco introduced this classic wardrobe piece that Vogue called "the new uniform of the modern woman"

(2, 2).clue: Many auteurs started out on this cartridge-loading 8mm format that Kodak introduced in 1965

(3, 2).clue: (Seinfeld's Jason Alexander gives the clue.)  Due to a "Trivial Pursuit" misprint, I insisted to the Bubble Boy Spain was once ruled by the Moops & not these people

(4, 2).clue: In 1969 he won his only Indy 500

(5, 2).clue: This "hearty" American astronomer known for his observatories invented the spectrohelioscope

(6, 2).clue: South African author Laurens Van Der Post called them the "first people of my native land"

(1, 3).clue: Chanel made this chic hotel on the Place Vendome her permanent home, & if you're well-heeled you can stay in her suite

(2, 3).clue: The Internet Movie Database says a 6 1/2 minute one of actress Meena Kumari in "Daera" is the longest on film

(3, 3).clue: This Caudillo kept Spain neutral during WWII

(5, 3).clue: Traveling in Malawi, Africa on July 6, 1861, this Scottish explorer saw "a large comet in Ursa Major"

(6, 3).clue: Growing up to 12 feet, it's a large venomous snake of Central America

(1, 4).clue: The J12, Chanel's first sport one of these, can be worn by men or women

(2, 4).clue: If a camera captures sound too, it's this word, like Sony's Handycam

(3, 4).clue: An 1872 Carlist revolt led to his abdication the following year; Falco might say, "Rock Me", this king!

(4, 4).clue: In 1985, he won the NHL Calder Memorial Trophy as the Rookie of the Year

(5, 4).clue: This observer of the heavens was the son of the governor of Helsingborg Castle

(6, 4).clue: The chivalric code of the samurai

(1, 5).clue: He moved from Germany to Paris at age 14 & entered the House of Chanel as artistic director in 1983

(2, 5).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew reports.)  To be precise, a pan moves a camera horizontally, while this is four-letter word for a vertical move

(3, 5).clue: In 1700 Philip V founded this dynasty in Spain; it was France's ruling dynasty from 1589 to 1792

(4, 5).clue: Called "The Voice of the Century", he played the title role in the 1951 film "The Great Caruso"

(5, 5).clue: In 1836, he noticed that light beads form around the edge of the moon during a solar eclipse

(6, 5).clue: A cylindrical metal sleeve used to prevent abrasion

(0, 0).clue: With Napoleon III's support, a physiological chemistry lab was created for him at the Ecole Normale Superieure
